Award.AwardTitle: Building New Spintronic Materials with Layered Chalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT

This award from the Condensed Matter Physics Program of the Division of Materials Research supports the University of Tennessee at Knoxville with a project focused on the design, discovery, and characterization of new materials for spintronics. Spintronics is the field that makes use of the electric charge and the spin (magnetic moment of the electron)of the electron to create new energy efficient device functionalities. Spintronics is a fast-developing field and it is expected to be further transformed by exploiting the properties of a class of material known as chalcogenides. Atomically thin layers of chalcogenides are true semiconductors and can lead to next generation of high performance electronic devices such as field-effect and photo- transistors. The fusion of spintronics with two dimensional chalcogenide semiconductors is expected to lead to revolutionary advances in nanoelectronics. As synthesis and crystal growth are excellent tools to reach undergraduate students, the research program is designed to actively involve undergraduates and kindle their interest in science. The hands-on experience of the students is complemented by a new course entitled "Nanomagnetism and Spintronics" to be taught at the advanced undergraduate level. In addition, the program supports the P.I.'s outreach activities, allowing the development of new demonstrations for middle school students based on superconductivity and magnetism.


TECHNICAL ABSTRACT

The objective of this project is to design, discover, and characterize new spintronic materials based on the remarkable electronic and magnetic properties of layered chalcogenides. The project is focused on two classes of spintronic materials. One class involves the formation of a chiral soliton lattice (CSL) in layered, metallic helical magnets. The CSL is a lattice of solitons (domain wall boundaries) separated by ferromagnetic regions. The CSL periodicity is tunable using modest applied fields and this effect is predicted to lead to unique spintronic functionalities, such as spin current induction, soliton transport, and current-driven collective transport. The second class of materials involves stoichiometric quasi-2D magnetic semiconductors with high mobility. These materials order magnetically and potentially can be used in single-layer devices that may be useful as spin injectors, sensors, or transducers. One of the goals of this project is to elucidate design principles for CSL materials and quasi-2D magnetic semiconductors. Single crystals of targeted materials are grown using both flux and vapor transport techniques. The anisotropic properties of the materials are characterized using SQUID magnetometry and electrical transport. Small angle neutron diffraction is performed to characterize the helical order of the CSL materials and probe their response to magnetic fields. Single-layer field-effect devices made from semiconducting 2D ferromagnets are fabricated and their electrical properties characterized. As synthesis and crystal growth are excellent tools to reach undergraduate students, the research program is designed to actively involve undergraduates and kindle their interest in science. The hands-on experience of the students is complemented by a new course entitled "Nanomagnetism and Spintronics" to be taught at the advanced undergraduate level. In addition, the program supports the P.I.'s outreach activities, allowing the development of new demonstrations for middle school students based on superconductivity and magnetism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  Spintronics describes the effort to use the magnetic properties of electrons--in addition to their charge--to create new and higher performance electronic devices and memories. One of the fundamental problems of spintronics is how to "control magnetism with electricity." What is desired is to be able to switch magnetism on and off, or perhaps change its character, merely by applying a voltage.

This is not an easy problem, because voltage couples to charge and not spin. The research being pursued by this project represents a fundamentally new approach to solving this problem. The key enabling development has been the evolution, in the nanoelectronics community, from graphene to transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs). TMDCs are remarkable materials because they can be mechanically exfoliated until they are only 3 atoms thick, but they remain good semiconductors and devices can be built from them.

It is possible to create magnetic materials that are quite similar to the TMDCs in that they can be mechanically exfoliated into layers only 3 atoms thick. As part of this project, we have created several such materials. The first material we have investigated is CrSiTe3. This material is a ferromagnetic semiconductor and has been theoretically predicted to remain ferromagnetic down to single layers. For the first time, we have created an field effect device from a nanoflake (70 nm thick) of layered magnetic chalcogenide and have measured its transfer characteristics. Although the performance of these first devices was not very good, these pioneering measurements indicate that this is a promising approach!   

The other main area in which this project has had impact is in the investigation of the "chiral soliton lattice" material Cr1/3NbS2. This material is of interest for spintronics because its electronic properties can be extensively modified with relatively small magnetic fields.    

Cr1/3NbS2 is a metallic, layered material that orders magnetically in the form of a long period (50 nm) helical magnet. The magnetic moments lie in the plane of the layers and spiral from layer to layer. When a magnetic field is applied parallel to the layers, the system responds by forming ferromagnetic regions separated by 360 degree domain walls known as "kinks" or "solitons." These ordered regions and solitons form a periodic structure called a "chiral soliton lattice." The term "chiral" simply means that the spiral ordering is constrained by the crystal structure to have only one "handedness" -- it spirals only one way. As the magnetic field is increased, the ferromagnetic regions grow larger, and the periodicity of the soliton lattice also grows larger. The change in the soliton lattice directly affects the electrical properties of the material.

As part of this project, single crystals of Cr1/3NbS2 were grown and extensively investigated. The crystals were studied using a variety of techniques, including angle resolved photoemission, neutron scattering, nanoscale transport, and magnetization. Considerable progress was made in understanding the electronic structure, magnetic phase diagram, and thickness dependence of the magnetoresistance. One of the most intriguing results is that as the thickness of the sample becomes comparable with the pitch of the helical order, the chiral soliton lattice is accommodated in the crystal through a series of "jumps" in the magnetoresistance.    

Broader impacts. This project supported the research of several graduate students, including three female students. Four undergraduates were involved in various aspects of the research and gained valuable lab skills. During one summer a high school student participated in the research. This project also helped to motivate a new course the P.I. is developing entitled "Quantum Mechanics for Engineers." As quantum technologies move from the laboratory to the marketplace, it is clear that engineers will need to have a better understanding of quantum mechanics.
